awd_titl_txt: CCRI: Planning-C: A Community Research Infrastructure for Integrated AI-Enabled Malware and Network Data Analytics
awd_abstract_narration:
The severity, frequency, scope, and sophistication of cybercrimes and cyberattacks have exploded in recent years, which resulted in huge financial damages to organizations, and threatened the critical infrastructures (e.g., energy grid, water safety, transportation, health care) and the most basic foundation of our society. While a host of open-source technologies for cybersecurity and for artificial intelligence have been developed and used by researchers in each community; research opportunities that leverage both of these technologies to tackle problems at the intersection of cybersecurity and artificial intelligence are not broadly accessible to cybersecurity community and AI community due to challenges, such as protection of sensitive information in network data, limited ground truth data, zero-day vulnerabilities, evasive malware, and processing voluminous and high-dimensional network data.

This Planning-C project, conducted in collaboration between Pennsylvania State University,  Merit Network, and University of Texas at Arlington, aims to broadly solicit inputs from the cyber security and AI research communities regarding (1) research opportunities of cybersecurity that can be addressed using artificial intelligence, and (2) associated infrastructures needs that are not broadly available to the research communities.  A tangle output of the planning workshop is to generate and publish a report in a suitable venue.  The outcome of this planning project will identify critical cybersecurity problems that can benefit from AI-enabled solutions as well as infrastructure requirements for these AI-enabled cyber security research that are not broadly accessible to the cybersecurity community and the AI community. 

The identification of these research opportunities and infrastructure needs at the intersection of cybersecurity and artificial intelligence will expedite the selection, integration, and adaptation of relevant open-source software tools and infrastructures, as well as the creation of new tools, as needed.  These tools and infrastructures will not only accelerate the critically needed advancement of cyber security solutions using AI, but also broaden the participation of early career scholars and students from under-represented groups in STEM in these research opportunities to further enhance the diversity of next-generation cybersecurity and AI workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This CCRI-Planning C project successfully convened a diverse group of artificial intelligence and cybersecurity experts from 25 organizations (20 academic institutions ranging from community colleges to R1 universities, 4 industry partners, and 1 government agency), located in 16 different states across all regions of the nation, to engage in a series of four half-day on-line workshops, spreading over two weeks (from Jan 20, 2023 to Feb 3, 2023) for identifying (1) research opportunities and challenges in cybersecurity that can be addressed using artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), and (2) associated infrastructure needs necessary for accelerating and democratizing research tasks for addressing existing and emerging cybersecurity challenges via the auspices of AI/ML.

Discussions of each day/session built  on outcomes of proceeding sessions, while they were all connected by a common thread involving three inter-related high-level topics: data acquisition and sharing, data analysis, and data governance.  The focus of the first day of the workshop was “Scoping”--- identifying important cybersecurity research problems that may be addressed by AI/ML.  This discussion at the workshop identified  research areas related to cybersecurity and AI, which are summarized in Table 1 of the Workshop Report.  The second day of the workshop started with “Visioning”, imaging future headlines in (1) data acquisition and sharing, (2) data analysis, and (3) data governance. One of the future headlines that were highlighted in the final report is  “Immune System for Cyberdefense --- Cybersecurity and AI  research community has risen to the challenge of securing critical national cyberinfrastructure by developing a cyber-immune system. The system is capable of detecting a host of different types of attacks and respond to them in ways that allow the system to recover and continue to function in the face of sophisticated attacks.”    Inspired by these visions, the workshop participants identified critical challenges and research opportunities for data acquisition and sharing, data analysis, and data governance.  These challenges are summarized in Section 2 of the workshop report.

Based on challenges identified by the community, the third day of the workshop focused on “Designing our Approach”.  More specifically, workshop participants were organized into three groups, each group focusing on one of the high-level topics (data acquisition and sharing, data analysis, and data governance), for brainstorming approaches, at the community level, the national level, and the individual levels, for building the envisioned tangible and intangible infrastructures that would help the AI/ML and cybersecurity communities overcome some of the challenges. These approaches are summarized in  Section 3 of the workshop report.

The focus of the final day of the workshop is “Identify the Infrastructure”.  Based on the approaches generated from Day 3, workshop participants identified high-priority infrastructure needs, which were classified into three broad categories: (1) data storage, collection, and analysis, (2) development of standards, policies, and legal frameworks, and (3) needs for support infrastructure, education, skill development and training.  These infrastructure needs are elaborated in Section 4 of the workshop report.

During the final hour of the workshop, an unexpected theme emerged -- the community of researchers that contribute, share, and use data, infrastructure and other resources, for performing research at the interface of AI/ML and cybersecurity needs to further grow, be diversified and enhanced.  Toward this community-building need, workshop participants identified characteristics of a high-performance community: (1) being inclusive and having a trusting culture, (2) driven by shared purposes, (3) empowered by artifacts, (4) supported by processes, (5) making societal impacts, and (6) being a community that fosters next generation researchers. This final outcome of the workshop is summarized in Section 5 of the workshop repor.

The workshop report has been distributed to all participants of the workshop to solicit inputs and feedback. The final report is available on the Web:
http://faculty.ist.psu.edu/yen/AICyberWS/NSF_Cybersecurity_AI_WS_report_FINAL.pdf

Broader Impacts:

The workshop identified critical opportunities for training and educating next-generation cybersecurity and AI knowledge workers, and attracting under-represented groups in STEM to careers related to cybersecurity and AI, using an infrastructure that integrates real-world cybersecurity problems, associated data, and exemplar AI/ML solutions for reducing the barriers for educators, students, and practitioners to boot-strap personal hands-on learning experiences for solving real-world cybersecurity problems using AI.  The workshop also identified a critical need to design and broadly disseminate training materials for people with different levels of knowledge.  By leveraging existing high performance computing (HPC) resources, these training materials can democratize the research capacity for educators, researchers, practitioners, and next-generation cybersecurity/AI knowledge workers to develop scalable AI-enabled solutions for cybersecurity problems.
